Prasenjit wrote:
>  From what I understand, if I use SURTPrefix and just provide a single 
> seed, it should crawl only those URIs which are residing on the seeded 
> host.  What this also implies is that at any point of time there should 
> be only 1 toe-thread running, because of the same-host politeness policy.
> 
> Are my assumptions/understanding correct ?

Mostly. However, by default Heritrix also assumes that if you've retrieved
a page, you want the inline resources necessary to render the page (aka
"embeds") as well -- images, frames, etc. -- even if they are on other hosts.
The same thing goes for an HTTP redirect response -- it's presumed if you
requested the first URI, you want whatever it redirected to. So those can
result in parallel fetches off your exact host/prefix.

If using DecideRule-based scoping (DecidingScope), you can disable this
behavior by leaving out the TransclusionDecideRule. (Or, configure it to
to be tighter than the default of up-to-3 non-navlink hops.)

Also, our pattern-based Javascript link extractor can't tell if the
plausible URIs it discovers are inline resources, in-place page reloads,
or clickable links -- so it treats them all as "speculative embeds" and
fetches them just like inline images. This can also cause offhost URIs
that aren't really necessary to render an in-scope page to be fetched.

Removing the ExtractorJS processor can mitigate this, but the ExtractorHTML
will still run Javascript extraction on inline scripts. There should also
be additional settings on ExtractorJS and ExtractorHTML to...
  - turn down the aggressiveness of, or turn off entirely, the Javascript
    URI extraction
  - control how Javascript-discovered URIs are treated -- as 'embeds'
    or something else
...but those settings aren't yet implemented.
